POST OFFICE SAVINGS BANK
(Commercialization)


    1. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for Finance, in view of the Post Office Savings Bank having more than two million savings accounts, what is the impact of the proposal of POSB going commercial on the account holders with

Column: 1132

regard to the tax exempt interest and if the Minister will provide details of the new scheme.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the tax-exempt status of interest on POSB deposits has been under review in the light of the plan to convert POSB into a commercial bank. The review is being undertaken by a Steering Committee, appointed to prepare the blueprint for commercialization. It has been addressing the question of the tax-

CRIME INVESTIGATION AND CONTROL
(Clearance rate for criminal offences)


    2. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what was the clearance rate of all the criminal offences committed in Singapore in 1980, 1981, and 1982; and (b) what measures his Ministry will take to improve the effectiveness of crime investigation and control.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the overall clearance rate for criminal cases in Singapore is as follows: 1980 28%; 1981 33%; 1982 29%.

    Our overall clearance rate for criminal cases is comparable to that of other highly developed countries in the world. For example, the overall clearance rate in Australia is 28.5%, Denmark is 23.2%, and the United States of America is 19.5%. However, among the developed countries Japan has achieved the highest overall clearance rate of 63.8%. This has been attributed to their koban system of policing. The koban police is responsible for more than 60% of the total number of criminal cases cleared in Japan. The Japanese koban police has been able to do this because of the excellent relationship they have with the residents in the neighbourhood, which is based on complete confidence and trust. As a result, the Japanese police has no difficulty in getting information on the presence of criminals, of crimes committed and getting the residents to be witnesses. Therefore, to improve the effectiveness of crime investigation and control, and thus the clearance rate of cases, it is not only necessary to upgrade the professional skills of police officers in crime investigation but, what is even more important, to forge a relationship of mutual trust and confidence between the police and the public so that members of the public will not hesitate to help the police in their investigations.

Column: 1134



NPP System

    The most important measure that my Ministry will take to achieve this objective is the introduction of the Neighbourhood Police Post (NPP) System. The NPP System is modelled after the Japanese koban system. It will ensure that police officers will always be close to all the residents and continually interact with them. An important feature of the NPP System is the home visit by NPP officers every six months to get to know the residents, listen to their views and suggestions and to offer their services. With the establishment of trust in the police officers, we can expect the vast majority of the residents to come forward to freely confide in the police officers and to volunteer information on the presence of criminals and strangers behaving suspiciously in the neighbourhood.

Crime Prevention

    The Police, however, is not relying solely on the NPP System to achieve the aim of total involvement with the community and its grassroots organizations. In the last two years, the first steps towards this objective have been taken with the introduction of the Neighbourhood Watch Scheme (NWS), the establishment of the National Crime Prevention Council and the formation of Boys' Clubs. The Crime Prevention Department has also made surveys of commercial premises with a view to advising the management and occupiers to get together to form crime prevention committees and implement crime prevention measures.

Upgrading of Skills

    The Police is also upgrading the professional skills of police officers in criminal investigation and other crime control activities. A team of British experts was asked to look into ways and means of improving the training facilities and the standard of instruction at the Police Academy. Many of their recommendations are now in the process of being implemented. Currently, the Police Academy runs many in-house courses on criminal investigation. Our crime investigators are also sent overseas for specialized training and attachments to learn new skills, particularly those relating to the investigation of commercial crime.

Column: 1135



Computerization

    To enhance the effectiveness of the Force in crime control, the Police is also implementing large scale computerization and mechanization of police operations. Command and control of patrol resources will be computerized by 1985. This computerized system will optimize the deployment of patrols and the allocation of resources in response to calls for Police assistance. Case management will be computerized by 1986 to ensure quicker processing and closer monitoring of crime cases.

    Besides these, the Police is also exploring other ways and means of mechanization and computerization such as in the lifting and matching of fingerprints and the collation of criminal intelligence. These will further help to improve the effectiveness of criminal investigations.

EXPATRIATES
(Procedures for employment)


    3. Dr Wan Soon Bee asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) what are the procedures for the approval of the applications by the expatriates to enter Singapore to take up employment; (b) how does the Immigration authority ascertain that the skills or expertise possessed by the applicants are required in Singapore; and (c) how does the Immigration authority prevent possible abuses by the applicants and/or sponsors.

    The Minister of State for Law and Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Sir, expatriates intending to take up employment in Singapore have to apply to the Immigration Department for Employment Passes if their monthly salaries exceed $1,000 per month. Applications are made in the prescribed forms and submitted through the employing company or a local sponsor. The applicant has to describe in the application form, his qualifications, working experience, duties to be performed and the details of the company which intends

Column: 1136

to engage his services. These forms are designed to enable the Immigration Department to obtain full information on the applicant's background and experience. The advice of relevant vetting authorities is also obtained before a decision is made. The main consideration in approving Employment Passes for expatriates is whether they are of economic benefit to Singapore.

    The applicant's qualifications and experience are the main factors which the Immigration Department considers in assessing each application for Employment Pass. The Department works within policy guidelines which have been drawn up by the Committee on Attracting Talents to Singapore (CATS). The Committee includes representatives from the Ministry of Trade and Industry and EDB. Amongst other things, the Committee is responsible for the identification, attraction and assimilation of non-Singaporean talent.

    When there is doubt about the professional standing or technical competence of the applicant, the Department will refer the application to the relevant Ministry or Department for advice. For example, if the applicant is from the banking sector, his application would be referred to the Monetary Authority of Singapore for vetting.

    Statistical data on the stock of Employment Pass holders, and on Employment Pass applications received, approved and rejected, are sent regularly to the Ministry of Trade and Industry for monitoring purposes.

    Each year Immigration Department receives thousands of applications for Employment Pass. The average number of applications per year for the last three years (1980-1982) was 21,820. The Immigration Department can only assess the applications based on information given by the applicants in the application forms and certified true by the employers or the sponsors. In most cases, the applications are decided within a month. In processing the applications, the officers will scrutinize the details in the application forms, and ask for documentary evidence to substantiate the statements made in the forms.

Column: 1137



    The Department's practice of referring doubtful cases to the relevant vetting authorities has also helped to minimize possible cases of abuse.

     Dr Wan Soon Bee (West Coast): Sir, is the Minister aware of the complaint that Singapore is becoming a training ground for redundant expatriates in their home countries and that such expatriates have deprived some Singaporeans of their jobs and promotions and this has created morale problems among the local managers? The unhappiness is not because the locals do not welcome the expatriates. In fact, all of us welcome all those expatriates who bring skills and expertise to our country. But it is because the locals are put to work -

     Mr Speaker: Dr Wan, what is your supplementary question? You are making a speech out of it.

     Dr Wan Soon Bee: I am coming to the question, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: Do that, please.

     Dr Wan Soon Bee: It is because the locals are put to work under those expatriates who are not qualified, less experienced and less capable than them. In view of this, would the Minister assure the House that, where such cases are uncovered, he will take prompt actions against them?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, I take it that the Member for West Coast is not disputing the objectives of the policy but raising a question as to its implementation, and I gather from his supplementary question that he has knowledge of complaints about possible abuse of persons coming in who are not qualified or have not the requisite qualifications.

    Let me assure him that if he has such information and if he were to send it to my Ministry, we will have it thoroughly investigated. If it is substantiated, I also wish to assure him that we will take prompt action and, if necessary, terminate the employment passes of those cases which are substantiated.

VACANT SHOPHOUSES NOS. 243 to 235
TANJONG PAGAR ROAD
(Measures to minimize fire hazards)


    4. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the Singapore Fire Service is aware of the very serious fire hazard presented by the state and condition of the vacant shophouses Nos. 243 to 235 Tanjong Pagar Road and what has been done or is being done to prevent or minimize the risk of further fires thereby endangering the lives of the residents in the other shophouses in the same stretch of shophouses.

    The Minister of State for Law and Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Fire Service is aware of the fire hazards posed by vacant buildings awaiting demolition. It has advised the relevant agencies, such as URA and HDB, on measures to be taken to minimize the fire hazards. These measures include the locking or the boarding up of the vacant buildings to deter trespassers and mischief makers. Furthermore, power supplies to such premises are also cut to prevent short circuits which may cause fires.

    There was a fire recently in the same row of shophouses referred to by the Member for Anson. The Fire Service did a splendid job in rescuing a family of four who were trapped in one of the burning shophouses. The fire started at No. 237 and spread to No. 235 Tanjong Pagar Road. Both premises were occupied at the time of the fire.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister of State says that the Fire Service is aware of the danger and has advised the relevant agencies. But I have been to this site twice and I find that the premises have all been left open. There are a lot of dried wood, debris lying about, and the residents in the neighbouring-

     Mr Speaker: Are you asking a supplementary question, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Yes, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: Can I have it, please?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Has anything been done about these particular premises - clearing the debris, the dried wood and locking them up to make them safe?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is evident, from the wording of the Question posed by the Member for Anson, that he clearly was under the impression that those shophouses Nos. 243 to 235 were vacant. I have just demonstrated by fact that two of them were not vacant at the material time but that three were vacant.

    The situation is that this row of shophouses is awaiting demolition. They can only be demolished when the residents have moved out. Some residents have moved out and the contractors who have been entrusted with demolition will begin to demolish those shophouses which are vacant, and when the others move out those too will be demolished. The Member for Anson can assist by encouraging or persuading the residents to move out of these, as he has pointed out, dangerous premises as soon as possible and thereby enable this condition to be eradicated.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Are we to understand, Mr Speaker, Sir, from the Minister of State that nothing has been done in these premises that are vacant, from Nos. 243 to 235, and that the dried wood has not been cleared away and that it will not be cleared away until all the other residents have moved out?

    May I tell the Minister and the Government that the neighbouring residents live in mortal fear. They are unable to go to bed at night because they are worried that there might be a fire and they begin to wonder whether the intention of the Ministry is that they should be forced out of their homes by fire.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, he has asked a question as to what the Fire Service has done, and I have given an answer. As far as those houses which are vacant are concerned, appropriate action will be taken by the Fire Service and the other departments, including the locking up and boarding up of vacant premises.

    With regard to those houses where the residents are still in those remises, like

Column: 1140

any other premises in Singapore, whether shophouses or not, the residents in those premises must ensure that they do not have debris and other flammable material lying within the premises.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am talking about the debris in the vacant houses.

VISUAL DISPLAY UNITS
(Legal norms for usage)


    5. Dr Wan Soon Bee asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour, in view of the widespread use of visual display units, if he will consider introducing legal norms concerning the use of visual display terminals, especially with a view to enabling the factory inspector to exercise control with special attention paid to the global effect of radiation to which workers are continuously exposed.

     The Minister of State for Labour (Dr Wong Kwei Cheong) (for the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, we appreciate the concern of the Member over the possible ill effects of radiation on workers operating visual display units (VDUs). VDUs do emit a low level of radiation which is no more than that emitted from a television set. This level of radiation is not harmful to the worker's health. This was the finding of the Department of Scientific Services of the Ministry of Health which conducted a test on VDUs in December 1980. The finding concurs with those in the UK and the US.

    However, it is recognized that prolonged work on a VDU may give rise to eye-strain and other complaints like fatigue, headache and muscle aches. These subjective complaints vary with individual operators and are more common under working conditions which do not cater to physical comfort. To minimize such complaints, many countries have drawn up guidelines on lighting, avoidance of glare, working postures, rest and hours of work.

    My Ministry has also, in 1981, prepared and issued a set of guidelines on visual display unit work. These guidelines were prepared after a study of recommendations made by authoritative bodies overseas. The include recommendations on

Column: 1141

work station design, for example, the-positioning of the keyboard, screen and seat; level of illumination; work-rest periods and medical examination. Because people are built differently and work in different ways, VDU work stations should be designed so that it can be adapted to the needs of individual operators. These guidelines may be used by management and operators to assess the adequacy of VDU work conditions.

     Dr Wan Soon Bee: Sir, would the Minister inform the House how to ensure that the guidelines recommended are being followed by the employers? And would the Minister also inform the House whether he will introduce legislation so that the level of radiation can be monitored by the Ministry to ensure that the radiation level of all VDUs is always maintained below the international standard set? Would the Minister also inform the House whether the cumulative effects of low level radiation will pose certain health hazards?

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the guidelines issued by the Ministry of Labour have been distributed to all concerned, i.e. employers and employer groups for implementation. The Industrial Health Department of the Ministry of Labour is monitoring and helping such employers to implement these guidelines. The Ministry is also liaising with the Department of Scientific Services of the Ministry of Health to ensure that the level of radiation remains at a low level so that the guidelines will continue to be kept by these employers and they will ensure that radiation will not be harmful to the workers.

    As for legislation, up to now -we have no evidence that radiation is harmful to workers. If the Member for West Coast has any such evidence and is able to show us such cases, I am sure the Ministry will be very happy to look into these instances. If there are sufficient cases to justify it, we will certainly consider legislation.

    On the point about cumulative effects, as long as the workers exposed to VDUs have sufficient break periods, for example, a 10-minute break after every two or three hours or lunch break which the worker would normally take, then it has been

Column: 1142

shown that the cumulative effects of such radiation are not harmful at all to the worker's health.

COMPREHENSIVE BUS STUDY
(Findings)


    6. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour if he will report on the findings of the Comprehensive Bus Study conducted by the Singapore Bus Service with the assistance of the London Transport International recently and when can residents of Telok Blangah and the neighbouring estates expect the introduction of a direct bus service between the Bukit Merah Interchange and Ang Mo Kio Interchange.

     The Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the recommendations of the Comprehensive Bus Study are being finalized and will only be available around April or May this year. I shall nevertheless briefly outline some of the more important preliminary findings to the House.

    A passenger survey was undertaken to determine accurately the travel patterns of bus passengers. Data from the passenger survey has been used to design a new bus network for the whole island to better match service to demand.

    The second major objective of the study was to devise a fare collection system that would allow SBS to convert all its services to one-man-operation. This is to make more efficient use of manpower. Although details are yet to be firmed up, the broad recommendation is to retain a distance-related fare structure and use ticket issuing machines that will record the time and place of boarding as well as the fare paid. For this system to work, we will need honest commuters because there will be no conductors on-board. Those caught riding beyond the fare paid will be asked to pay a penalty fare.

    A key feature of the proposed fare collection system is "through ticketing", that is to say, passengers having to transfer from one bus to another will not have to

Column: 1143

pay a second time. Season tickets with appropriate discounts will also be introduced.

    Although the majority of commuters can expect to benefit from the changes proposed by the study, details will have to be carefully examined to ensure that as few people as possible are adversely affected. The proposed changes will be implemented in stages starting around end of this year or early next year.

    The possibility of a direct bus service between Ang Mo Kio and Telok Blangah will also be looked into as part of the overall revised bus network, details of which will be made known after the network has been finalized.

BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY
(Projected labour requirements)


    7. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the projected labour requirement of the building and construction industry in the next five years; (b) how many of the jobs will be taken up by Singaporeans; and (c) whether our aim of building up a good core of Singaporean construction workforce is attainable.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lee Yock Suan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, based on construction projects in the pipeline, including major public projects, such as the MRT, the building and construction industry, barring unforeseen circumstances, will remain buoyant in the next five years. It is estimated that about 25,000 new jobs in the construction industry will be available in the next five years for our job seekers. Many of these jobs will require higher-level skills both in handling construction machinery and in building construction trades.

    20% to 25% of the job vacancies is likely to be filled by Construction Brigade enlistees. The balance will be available for other Singaporeans. In the present slack economic situation, we hope more Singa-

Column: 1144

poreans will realize that the construction industry can offer them skills training and good pay and be attracted to join the industry. Indeed our survey shows that most Construction Brigade trainees after one year's training, are earning more than $20 per day, plus CPF contributions from the employer.

    We have made some progress in building up a core of Singaporean construction workforce. Core contractors working for the Housing and Development Board are required to employ a certain number of permanent skilled and professional workforce for their jobs, including the employment of Construction Brigade enlistees. Besides core contractors, other reputable HDB contractors are also encouraged to employ Construction Brigade enlistees. HDB contractors are presently employing 348 Construction Brigade enlistees and providing on-the-job training to 986 other enlistees on their work sites. The Public Works Department will also be requiring its contractors to employ on a permanent basis professional and skilled manpower if they want to tender for major public sector jobs. The Construction Industry Training Centre, which is planned to begin enrolment towards the end of this year, will help to produce the necessary skilled manpower required by the industry.

    Over the longer term, as the industry upgrades, mechanizes and industrializes the resultant productivity growth will lessen the need for more manpower, especially foreign workers. It is still the aim of the Government to phase out foreign workers in the construction workforce by 1991.

LOW WATER PRESSURE IN HDB FLATS
(Complaints)


    8. Mr Rohan bin Kamis asked the Minister for National Development if he is aware of the numerous complaints by the residents of top floors of Housing and Development Board flats of low water pressure; what steps have been taken to rectify the problem; what is the progress of the correction programme, and what can the residents do to help alleviate the problem.

Column: 1145



     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB is aware of the problem of low water pressure at the top floors of HDB blocks. An improvement programme is in progress to install separate downfeed pipes to increase the flow of water to the top two floors of high-rise blocks. 1,971 blocks are included in the programme and 62% have undergone improvements so far. The programme will be fully completed by March next year.

    There is no necessity for residents to take further measures, beyond what HDB is already doing, to alleviate the problem. It would be helpful, however, if residents understand the nature of the problem and HDB's remedial action.

ROAD, BERNAM STREET AND ENGGOR STREET

    10. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for National Development if he will explain the delay in determining the compensation payable and in allocating alternative accommodation to the owners and occupiers of properties in the area bounded by Tanjong Pagar Road, Bernam Street and Enggor Street when the owners

Column: 1146

and occupiers have all been given notice to quit their premises by the 31st January, 1983.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Anson will refer to Vol. 42, No. 2 of the Hansard, in other words, if he will do his homework, he will find that I had, at the sitting on 31st August, 1982, described for him at length the necessary legal procedures in the clearance process.

    I had said that Notices to Quit are prescribed by the law to formally notify squatters that they are affected by resettlement action and have to vacate the site. After the service of the Notices, parallel action is taken by the Resettlement Department to determine the eligibility of those affected for resettlement benefits, including offer of alternative accommodation or cash compensation. I had emphasized in my reply that resettlement benefits are ex-gratia in nature and may be offered to affected residents at any point in the clearance process, not necessarily immediately after the service of the Notice to Quit. I had also assured the Member that no physical eviction action is taken until the Resettlement Department has offered alternative accommodation or cash compensation to those who are eligible.

    In the area referred to by the Member for Anson, the Resettlement Department is currently in the process of determining the eligibility of affected persons. There has been no undue delay. Compensation will be paid when the interviews are over and alternative accommodation will be offered when facilities are available. No eviction action will be taken before this is completed.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am obliged to the Minister of State, but I would ask whether he would convey his answer to the Minister of State for Home Affairs. We were told just a little while ago that I should persuade them to move out. Now we understand from the Minister of State for National Development that they have not been offered alternative accommodation as yet. They have not been offered resettlement benefits. So I would ask him to lend his voice to my plea to the Minister for Home Affairs and to the Fire

Column: 1147

Service to do something to protect the lives of those citizens who are still living there until such time as the Ministry is able to get them out.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid the Member for Anson may not be familiar with the situation in this particular part of his constituency. In actual fact, the development in this area, which has been acquired by the URA, consists of two phases. The first phase has already been more or less settled. The people there have been given offers of compensation, alternative accommodation, and so on. Some of them are choosy and are still there. They are, therefore, facing the hazard of fire which is unavoidable in any resettlement site. You cannot expect the Government officers to keep going to those places and telling them, "Clear the debris. You are facing a fire hazard".

    What the Member is asking about concerns Phase 2, where the notices to quit were served only on 1st January this year, and I have already given him the answer. He should have checked clearly with the residents which phase they belong to.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have referred to a particular area, Tanjong Pagar Road, where there was a fire two weeks ago and a fire before that. The residents adjoining these vacant shop houses told me that the question of their compensation had not been determined. They told me there was another problem. During these meetings, the details on the restructure of the GES and the amendments of its rules, by-laws and regulations to tighten control over its members were discussed.

    The GES in its Extraordinary General Meeting on 11 February 1983 has approved the proposed amendments to its Articles of Association drawn up by its Management.

    The main changes to the GES Articles of Association and rules are:-

    a. Legal status of the GES

    The GES, formerly a private company incorporated under the Companies Act, has been converted into a public limited company to cater for an enlarged membership.(Under the Companies Act, a private company can only have a maximum of 50 shareholders/members.)

    b. GES Committee

    The GES Committee is the main executive body of the exchange and has been vested with all the powers of the exchange for the management of the affairs of the exchange. Membership of this

    Committee has been increased from six to eight members of which two will be representatives from the MAS. The remaining six will be elected by members in a General Meeting from the candidates nominated. The nominees will have to be approved by the MAS. The objective of this

    amendment is to enable the MAS to play a more direct role in the initial supervision and development of the GES.

    c. Sub-Committee

    Two sub-committees, each with three members have been formed. These are the Membership Sub-Committee and Disciplinary Sub-Committee, which will take charge of membership applications and disciplinary matters respectively.

    d. Disciplinary Action and Appeal

    The principle of 'show cause' has been introduced as a new rule for disciplinary action. If any member (clearing and non-clearing) fails to comply with any of the GES Articles, rules, by-laws or regulations, the Disciplinary Sub-Committee would require the member concerned to 'show cause' as to why he should not be reprimanded, suspended or expelled or be subject to such other action as the Sub-Committee may deem fit. A member who considers himself aggrieved by any decision of the Disciplinary Sub-Committee may appeal to the GES Committee and the decision of the Committee shall be final.

    e. Discretionary Accounts

    A new provision has been incorporated in this rule to discourage the operation of discretionary accounts except when a member has obtained specific approval from the GES Committee. Approval for the operation of discretionary accounts will only be given under strict terms and conditions. The MAS has asked the GES to propose a standard format of agreement for the operation of discretionary accounts for its approval.

    f. Auditing Requirements

    A new provision has also been incorporated in the GES rules giving the GES Committee power to appoint auditors at any time to inspect the books of its members.

    g. Changes in the Ownership and Control of Member Company

    The amended Article of the GES would require a member to seek approval from the Membership Sub-Committee before any change in the legal or beneficial ownership or change in the control of the member company can take place. This is to ensure that an unscrupulous operator would not become a member by buying into an existing member company.

    The amendments will empower the GES to supervise and regulate its members and to cater for the expansion and development of the exchange. A technical sub-committee was appointed to make further study of the by-laws and regulations which will govern the business conduct and practices of gold trading.

    Some of the proposals approved by the MAS are:-

    a. To extend the by-laws and regulations to cover the conduct of associate members of the GES. Previously, they applied only to full members of the GES.

    b. To introduce a by-law to prohibit the practice of 'churning' of the accounts of customers. 'Churning' is the buying and selling of contracts by the broker at the same price. Some brokers have been engaging in the practice of 'churning' of the accounts of their customers in order to earn more commission.

    c. a new by-law would be added to ensure that all kerb trading are reported promptly. Kerb trades are deals done after GES trading hours (that is, transactions done at night) and which are to be reported the following day. Certain guidelines would be drawn up by the exchange to monitor kerb trading and to ensure that kerb trades are actually done at the proper market price range.

    d. a new provision would be included to disallow firms from misrepresenting facts to the clients.

    The technical sub-committee is also studying the feasibility of imposing segregated account requirements for the protection of clients. This is to ensure that clients' funds, placed with the gold trading company as margin deposit, are kept separately from the members' so that the investors' interest would be protected.

    The GES is currently studying a proposal to expand into financial futures trading activities. In this connection, the possibility of an institutional link with an overseas exchange for trading in both gold and financial futures is under study. A project manager from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange is now in Singapore studying the details of the link- up between Singapore and the International Monetary Market. There are advantages in establishing such a link but the problems are not inconsiderable.

    I would like to point out that the changes that have been made only cover the main areas of concern. As the exchange matures and gains more experience, more rules, by-laws and regulations would be amended or introduced to ensure the development of an orderly and efficient market.

    May I end on a word of caution. The gold market and more especially the futures market, here as elsewhere, will attract speculators. Speculators are usually people with strong gambling propensities. While regulations properly enforced can curb the worst excesses of speculation, there is no way the Government can save people who are determined to part with their money from the consequences of their own folly. The reports on the 24 gold trading companies, should my colleague the Minister for Law decide to publish them, will bear me out on this point.
